creator: pietro.licata@sistinf.it
text:
I am using a java.util.ResourceBundle into my JSP: java.util.ResourceBundle rb 
= java.util.ResourceBundle.getBundle("client");
If I put the client.properties file into the same directory as the JSP, 
everyting works fine. If I put the client.properties into a subdirectory (e.g. 
props/client.properties) and I change the constructor accordingly: 
java.util.ResourceBundle rb = java.util.ResourceBundle.getBundle
("props.client"); I get the following error: javax.servlet.ServletException: 
Can't find bundle for base name props.client, locale it_IT.
The same directory structure works well with WebSphere v3.02.

Java resources are managed by the class loader, and thus the resource file 
(either .class or .properties) must be visible to the class loader.  The JSP 
1.1 specification defines what classes are available to the class loader (see 
section 5.3.2).  Classes in WEB-INF/classes, classes JAR files in WEB-INF/LIB 
(and indirectly through those JAR files' class-path manifest entries) are 
visible.  Regardless of where the JSP source file is located, the properties 
must be in either WEB-INF/classes directory tree or in a JAR in WEB-INF/lib.

I tested an application that put the properties in WEB-INF/classes and in WEB-
INF/class/prop (adjusting the paramter to getBunder() appropriately) and the 
resources were loaded properly in both cases.

text: Marc Saegesser's comments don't solve the problem when using .properties files.

Antonio,
the answer given by Marc is correct. I opened the bug because of the difference
between Tomcat's default class path and WebSphere's one. Later, I double-checked
Tomcat's class path, I put .properties files accordingly and Tomcat worked fine,
too.
